Authors:
Nina du Toit, Bettine Jansen van Vuuren, Sonja Matthee,
Conrad A. Matthee
Title:
Biome specificity of distinct genetic lineages within the
four-striped mouse, Rhabdomys pumilio (Rodentia: Muridae) from southern
Africa with implications for the taxonomy
Keywords:
Rhabdomys, taxonomy, biomes, ecological niche modelling,
relaxed molecular clock, southern Africa
Abstract:
Within southern Africa, a link between past climatic
changes and faunal diversification has been hypothesizedestablished for
a diversity of taxa. To test the hypothesis that evolutionary
divergences may be correlated to vegetation changes (induced(driven by
changes in climate),drives evolutionary divergences, we selected the
widely distributed four-striped mouse, Rhabdomys, as a model. Two
species are currently recognized, the mesic-adapted R. dilectus and
arid-adapted R. pumilio. However, the morphology-based taxonomy and the
distribution boundaries of previously described subspecies remain poorly
defined. The current study, which spans across seven biomes, focuses on
the spatial genetic structure of 521the arid-adapted R. pumilio (521
specimens from 31 localities) and includes limited sampling of the
mesic-adapted R. dilectus (33 specimens from 10 localities) to fully
capture variation within the genus. and 33 R. dilectus specimens from 10
localities, spanning seven different biomes The mesic R. dilectus was
included solely as taxonomic reference. The mitochondrial COI gene and
four nuclear introns (Eef1a1, MGF, SPTBN1, Bfib7) were usedutilized as
molecular markers for the construction of gene trees. Mitochondrial DNA
analyses indicate that Rhabdomys consistsmprise of four reciprocally
monophyletic, geographically structured clades, with three distinct
lineages present within the arid- adapted R. pumilio. These monophyletic
lineages differ by at least 7.98.6% (±0.32) and these results are partly
confirmed by a neighbour-multilocus network of the combined nuclear
intron dataset. Ecological niche modelling in MaxEnt supports a strong
correlation between regional biomes and the distribution of distinct
evolutionary lineages of Rhabdomys. A Bayesian relaxed molecular clock
suggestsed that the geographic clades diverged between 3.294.24 Ma,
supporting the hypothesis that the radiation within the genus coincides
with climatic changes (and the establishment of the biomes)
characterizing the Miocene-Pliocene boundary. Marked genetic divergence
at the mitochondrial DNA level, coupled withto strong nuclear and mtDNA
signals of non-monophyly of R. pumilio, support the notion that a
taxonomic revision of the genus is needed.
